column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $1$1$5$"I was prescribed this medication by my psychiatrist along with Cipralex (escitalopram) for anti-depression. I have since stopped taking both but while I was on them both I was very uncomfortable and I was far more mentally unstable. I was very aggressive and lethargic.

column1: While escitalopram isn't listed as one of the drugs it can react with I would still say to be careful with it. At the time I was under 18 and I'd approximate about 130lbs
column2: and 5'2"" if that helps. Sex is female."
19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$3$Diagnosed Bipolar. Weight gain is obvious. I had to take it daily
column3: and I was getting used to that. Manic state is more controlled now
column4: but I hated the weight gain... I'm having difficulty losing it now. Anyway

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$2$2$its good ....

55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Good drug except for weight gain and heartburn. Doc says it's the Remeron that causes the weight gain. I think it is the Remeron and the Valproic Acid. I take 500 mgs in am and 500 mgs at night.

55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$After years of fighting Depression the new Dr. tried this med and it started to work for the better. I didn't know I was bi-polar but my new wife did and she wasn't afraid to speak up as she too deals with depression.
45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$4$Have been taking from 750 to 1000mg for about 5 years. Weight gain seems to be the most noticable side effect
column4: then infrequent fluctuations of approx. 5 lbs or so. I also take sertraline; buproprion

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$3$5$Initially my mood was stabilized on this med for 5-6 months. About the 4-5th month I experienced swollen and painfulness in my right hand. It was easy to use in the liquid form.
55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Was prescribed valproic acid after a psychotic break arrested with lithium and prozac.  Initially diagnosed with depression
column3: subsequently altered to bipolar disorder.  Have been on 750 mg divided dose for several years
column4: no significant side effects.  Went off medication for 3 months
column5: had a manic episode characterized by wild overspending and other dangerous behaviors.  Resumed medication regimen and brought symptoms under control within 3 weeks.  I have had good success with this medication.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$

25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$1$3$In the beginning this medication worked great for my Bipolar/ Manic Depression. My only complaint was the indigestion it gave me. I started gaining a lot of weight and my hair started falling out at around 4 months. I have gained 35 lbs in 5 months and lost over half my hair by the time my doctor told me to stop this medication. I had decreased my dose to 1/4 mgs until I could see her. This caused me to become more anxious than ever and began having bad anxiety attacks. Been off it for 2 weeks and my hair is still falling out really bad. My pharmacist suggested I take AG Pro (behind the counter at Wal-Mart but non-prescription). I am extremely unsatisfied with this medication and wish I had never started taking it.

35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$3$5$I am happy with how stable my emotions are but I have gained over 50 pounds and 12 dress sizes in less than 10 months (on the meds for 12 mos.).  I still eat right and exercise

56$Bipolar Depression$4/28/2009 11:39:20 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$1$I am a 135lb female who was put on 1500mg of this immediately and was told that my blood level was fine
column2: I was almost comatose! I couldn't get off the couch for days on end
column3: finally my local doctor lowered my dose and I am now down to 250mg daily--I fell human again
column4: I'll take the depression over this!

column1: 57$Bipolar Depression$10/27/2008 8:17:41 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$3$2$On this and Abilify. I'm not quite feeling myself just yet. This medication gives me bad heartburn. I also experience blurred vision after taking my meds. Not so much weight gain
column2: but it does make my head feel a little funny.

35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$2$1$I am Bipolar and have a seizure disorder.  I am frustrated that I have to take 10 - 250mg pills to get the correct does.  That's a lot of pills!  It is also the only medication I can afford.  I have hair loss and hand tremors.  I don't know about weight gain.  I don't think I can attribute all my weight gain to my meds.  I'm lazy.  I don't feel it controls all my bipolar symptoms and I don't want to increase my dose any further.  I would love to try something else with fewer pills that I could still afford.

column1: 63$Bipolar Depression$11/17/2007 11:54:07 AM$Reviewer: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$3$5$Recetly diagnosed with Bi-Polar. First medication. Changed to DIVALPROEX. Mood correction the same but food intolerance came back.

column1: 8$Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$8/14/2014 5:45:36 PM$Reviewer: $5$5$5$"I could write a novel on Rx Bi-polar meds after dealing with bi-polar for over 20 yrs.  The true issue is preventing manic episodes.  Valproic is one of only 3 meds that do that well
column2: and also stop them during a manic phase.  The meds work great for both!  I have been on and off them due to side effect concerns.  They are NOT good for your liver.  Your liver is a super organ that does so many things for you.  I have been off this med for over a year now.  I have no depression and no manic episodes.  Getting ALL nutrients
column4: adequate sleep and avoiding STESS is key.  Bi-polar is not a disease
column5: it is a nutrient deficiency that causes imbalances in neurotransmitters!  People dealing with ""bi-polar"" need ALL nutrients and it will go away.  These meds are invaluable to bring a manic episode under control
column7: they due not ""cure the disease"".  The cure is nutrients...ALL of them!  The key nutrients for the neurotransmitters for bi-polar are: FOLATE (Not
column8: absolutely not folic acid! Never consume folic acid!!)
column13: & MAGNESIUM. Research on the net food sources for them
column15: 99% of all ""vitamin supplements"" are not vitamins.  Even the ones at health food stores!  They are pharmaceutical grade analogs (PGA's).  They are horrible for your body
column17: and do not work in the same way as REAL vitamins from REAL food.  If you research PGA's and how they make them and from what you will be horrified!  Do not put them in your body!  Instead
column18: research ""real food source vitamin supplements"" and choose a good one.  The one I selected is from Sunwarrior company because it had the adequate levels and correct ratios of B vitamins.  I make a shake every morning with Gold Standard Whey protein powder
column23: empty the herbs & supplements caps into it.  I eat only whole
column25: real food. That's all nutrients in a glass!"

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver) $3$3$3$Honestly
column3: can't... Only answered q.2 b/ci it was required. Would very much like to know if this would-be a good candidate for treating my manic episodes. Usually in fits and spurts
column4: a good estimate would be 6 manic episodes per year max. They are however
column5: lengthy and a pain to my husband and son as well
column6: that they endure somehow... I take klonapin in a small dose every day as a means to help my mind wind-down and generally relax enough to fall asleep within 30 min or less rather then the 2-3 hours it normally can take. I also take fiorinal w/ codeine to combat stress-related migraines I suffer from at least once per week. I take that only when headache/migraine persists. What might be the best prescription drug to add to this carefully concocted cocktail of medications so far.
